questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother says his teachers report him being easily distracted, lagging behind his classmates in most of the subjects, and frequently falling asleep during class. She says that her son has complained of leg pain on multiple occasions. He is at the 45th percentile for height and 35th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ptosis and a high-arched palate. Muscle strength is decreased in the face and hands. Muscle strength of the quadriceps and hamstrings is normal. Sensation is intact. Percussion of the thenar eminence causes the thumb to abduct and then relax slowly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Becker muscular dystrophy manifests with muscle weakness in boys between the ages of 5–10. However, this weakness typically involves the proximal muscles of the lower limb (thigh and hip muscles). Extraocular muscles and distal muscles of the upper limb are almost always spared.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis may present with myotonia. However, the myotonia in patients with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis characteristically increases with fasting, after exercise, or in cold weather. Moreover, patients typically present with dramatic episodes of weakness that predominantly affect proximal muscles rather than the insidiously developing distal muscle weakness seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain mild forms of spinal muscular atrophy (SMA; e.g., Kugelberg-Welander disease) may manifest during late childhood with limb weakness and muscle pain (due to cramps). However, unlike in this patient, proximal muscles of the lower limb are usually more severely affected. Also, the upper cranial nerve nuclei are typically spared in patients with SMA and ptosis would therefore not be present. Although certain motor milestones may be delayed, cognitive development is typically normal in children with spinal muscular atrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

McArdle disease may result in muscle weakness, myalgia, and exercise intolerance. However, McArdle disease usually manifests during late adolescence or early adulthood and results in generalized muscle weakness or weakness that affects proximal muscles more than distal ones. One characteristic feature of McArdle disease is the second wind phenomenon, i.e., the relief of muscle pain and weakness after a brief episode of rest, which is absent in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Myotonia (as indicated by abduction of the thumb followed by slow relaxation upon percussion), myalgia, and muscle weakness in the distal muscles (hand and/or foot), face, as well as extraocular muscles, are highly suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy. Reduced fetal temporalis and pterygoid muscle growth results in a high-arched palate. About 50% of patients with myotonic dystrophy have some degree of cognitive impairment. Other clinical features that are commonly associated with myotonic dystrophy include frontal balding, which typically develops during adolescence, testicular atrophy or features of ovarian insufficiency, and bilateral cataracts. The diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy can be established by electromyography and genetic testing.

Type 1 myotonic dystrophy can develop at birth, during childhood, or during adulthood.

F) INCORRECT:

Juvenile-onset dermatomyositis manifests with lower limb weakness in children between the ages of 5 and 10 years. However, cutaneous manifestations such as a heliotrope rash over the eyelids and cheeks, or a dry scaly eruption over the knuckles (Gottron's sign) would also be present.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) would present with muscle weakness and symptoms of intellectual impairment in boys. However, weakness typically appears before the age of 5 years and predominantly affects the hip and thigh muscles (positive Gower's sign and/or waddling gait). Pseudohypertrophy of the calves is another important sign that is present in 60% of children with DMD. Extraocular muscles and distal muscles of the upper limb are almost always spared, even in the late stages of the disease (unlike this child who has ptosis and hand weakness).
questions.hint: This autosomal dominant condition is caused by an expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat in the DMPK gene.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after losing consciousness. He had no preceding chest pain or palpitations. His father has cataracts and had frontal balding in his twenties but has no history of cardiac disease. His paternal grandfather also had early-onset balding. His pulse is 43/min. Physical examination shows frontal hair loss, temporal muscle wasting, and testicular atrophy. Neurologic examination shows bilateral foot drop and weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles. An ECG shows bradycardia with third-degree atrioventricular block. The severity of this patient's symptoms compared to that of his father is most likely due to which of the following genetic properties?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pleiotropy is the production of two or more seemingly unrelated phenotypical changes by a single gene. While this patient's condition does exhibit pleiotropy (for example, with his frontal balding and AV heart block), this does not explain why the patient's symptoms are more severe than his father or grandfather, or why he is exhibiting symptoms at a younger age.

B) INCORRECT:

If there is loss of heterozygosity of a tumor suppressor gene, a single mutation in the remaining copy can lead to the development of cancer (e.g., Li-Fraumeni syndrome). However, this phenomenon is not associated with this patient's inheritable MMD and does not explain more severe symptoms at a younger age.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the phenotype in codominance is influenced by both alleles, if this patient's disease were codominant, we would expect that his phenotype would be in between that of his mother and his father. However, his mother is not affected by the disease and his father has a less severe presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Incomplete penetrance explains why some people with a disease genotype do not express the disease phenotype. It does not explain this patient's variation in severity of the phenotype between the generations.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has more severe manifestations of disease than his father or grandfather, and at a younger age. This phenomenon, called anticipation (genetics), is common in trinucleotide repeat disorders such as myotonic dystrophy type I, Huntington disease, and fragile X syndrome. Trinucleotide repeat expansion leads to increasing numbers of repeated sequences of trinucleotides in each generation, which in turn causes greater defects in the affected genes and earlier onset of associated symptoms.
questions.hint: Heart conduction disorders (bradycardia, arrhythmia), testicular atrophy, myotonia, and frontal balding are signs of myotonic muscular dystrophy (MMD) type 1. Inheritance of this condition is autosomal dominant.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurring episodes of achy muscle pain in his legs. He has a history of poor school performance despite tutoring and has been held back two grades. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. Examination shows ptosis, a high-arched palate, and muscle weakness in the face and hands; muscle strength of the quadriceps and hamstrings is normal. Sensation is intact. Percussion of the thenar eminence causes the thumb to abduct and then relax slowly. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?

choices.text: Defect of voltage-gated sodium channels of the sarcolemmal membrane
Complete impairment of the dystrophin protein
Partial impairment of the dystrophin protein
Humoral immune attack against the endothelium of capillaries
CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is the underlying cause of spinal muscular atrophy. Certain mild forms of spinal muscular atrophy (e.g., Kugelberg-Welander disease) may present during late childhood with limb weakness and muscle pain (due to cramps). However, unlike in this patient, proximal muscles of the lower limb are usually more severely affected. Also, the upper cranial nerve nuclei are typically spared in patients with SMA and ptosis would therefore not be present. Although certain motor milestones may be delayed, cognitive development is typically normal in children with spinal muscular atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

A defect of voltage-gated sodium channels of the sarcolemmal membrane is the underlying cause of hyperkalemic periodic paralysis. Patients with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis may present with myotonia. However, the myotonia in patients with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis characteristically increases with fasting, after exercise, or in cold weather. Moreover, patients typically present with dramatic episodes of weakness that predominantly affect proximal muscles rather than the insidiously developing distal muscle weakness seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is the underlying cause of McArdle disease, which may result in muscle weakness, myalgia, and exercise intolerance. However, McArdle's disease usually presents during late adolescence or early adulthood and results in generalized muscle weakness or weakness that affects proximal muscles more than distal ones. One characteristic feature of McArdle disease is the second wind phenomenon, the relief of muscle pain and weakness after a brief episode of rest, which is absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Complete impairment of the dystrophin protein is the underlying cause of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) would present with muscle weakness and symptoms of intellectual impairment in boys. However, weakness typically appears before the age of 5 years and predominantly affects the hip and thigh muscles (positive Gower's sign and/or waddling gait). Pseudohypertrophy of the calves is another important sign that is present in 60% of children with DMD. Extraocular muscles and distal muscles of the upper limb are almost always spared, even in the late stages of the disease (unlike this child who has ptosis and hand weakness).

Although facial muscle weakness may occur in DMD (resulting in a typical facies with wide palpebral fissures, loss of nasolabial folds, and a staring lack of expression), it is usually a very late feature.

E) INCORRECT:

Partial impairment of the dystrophin protein is the underlying cause of Becker muscular dystrophy, which presents with muscle weakness in boys between the ages of 5–10. However, this weakness typically involves the proximal muscles of the lower limb (thigh and hip muscles). Extraocular muscles and distal muscles of the upper limb are almost always spared.

F) INCORRECT:

Humoral immune attack against the endothelium of capillaries is the underlying cause of dermatomyositis. Juvenile-onset dermatomyositis would present with lower limb weakness in children between the ages of 5 and 10 years. However, cutaneous manifestations such as a heliotrope rash over the eyelids and cheeks, or a dry scaly eruption over the knuckles (Grotton sign) would also be present.

G) CORRECT:

CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene is the underlying cause of myotonic dystrophy. Abduction of the thumb followed by slow relaxation upon percussion indicates myotonia. Myotonia in a 10-year-old boy with muscle aches and weakness in the distal muscles (hand and/or foot), face, and extraocular muscles is highly suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy. Reduced fetal temporalis and pterygoid muscle growth result in a high-arched palate. About 50% of patients with myotonic dystrophy have some degree of cognitive impairment, which likely explains his poor school performance. Other clinical features that are commonly associated with myotonic dystrophy include frontal balding, which develops typically during adolescence, and bilateral cataracts. The diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy can be established by electromyography and genetic testing.
questions.hint: Other common features of this autosomal dominant condition include arrhythmias and testicular atrophy.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after the sudden onset of weakness in his legs and upper arms. He explains that he has been under a lot of stress lately preparing for a set of important exams. He had a similar episode 7 months ago the first night after finishing a football tournament with his high school. At the time, the weakness lasted 5 hours and resolved completely without treatment. At follow-up examination 1 week later, the results of a complete blood count, routine serum studies, and an MRI of the brain and spine showed no abnormalities. Medical and family history is otherwise unremarkable. He is not sexually active. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. He smokes 2–3 cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the hip flexors and knee extensors, 3/5 in the shoulder abductors, and 4/5 in all other muscle groups. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ throughout. Sensation is intact. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination of the cranial nerves shows no abnormalities. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is normal. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) can manifest with episodic muscle weakness after stress or exertion, and the proximal limb muscles are usually more affected when the extremities are involved. However, isolated extremity involvement is highly uncommon as an initial manifestation of MG. The small muscles (e.g., extraocular muscles, bulbar muscles) are typically the first to be affected, and involvement of the extremities usually occurs in advanced disease. In addition, the deep tendon reflexes are normal in MG. Moreover, this patient's ECG findings are consistent with a particular electrolyte abnormality, which indicates a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), which typically affects male individuals and has a symptom onset during adolescence, manifests with proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, BMD is characterized by a constant, progressively worsening course, rather than self-resolving episodes. The typical ECG findings of BMD are the result of cardiac fibrosis and dilated cardiomyopathy (e.g., pathological Q waves in the inferior and lateral leads, tall R waves in the precordial leads). BMD can cause a prolonged PR interval (as a result of an atrioventricular block due to cardiac fibrosis) but not prominent U waves.

C) INCORRECT:

Pure motor stroke is typically caused by embolism, and this patient's previous episode of weakness could have been caused by a transient ischemic attack, which is a harbinger for stroke. However, bilateral weakness that predominantly involves the proximal muscle is inconsistent with the occlusion of any specific blood vessel in the CNS. This patient also has no risk factors for pediatric embolic strokes such as septal defects (which cause paradoxical embolism) and valvular atrial fibrillation (e.g., due to rheumatic heart disease). His ECG findings are consistent with a particular electrolyte abnormality, which indicates a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Functional neurological symptom disorder may manifest with episodes of weakness in a patient who has recently experienced psychologic stress. However, the diagnosis can only be established in patients whose symptoms cannot be explained by any recognized medical condition. This patient's ECG findings, which indicate a particular electrolyte abnormality, and his clinical presentation indicate an organic cause for his illness.

E) CORRECT:

Episodes of proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia with concomitant ECG findings of hypokalemia are consistent with hypokalemic periodic paralysis (hypoKPP). HypoKPP, the most common cause of periodic paralysis, is typically caused by incompletely penetrant, autosomal dominant mutations of sarcolemmal calcium or sodium channels. These mutations exaggerate the potassium influx that occurs in response to physiological triggers such as sympathetic activation (e.g., during stress or physical exertion) and insulin release (e.g., following a high-carbohydrate meal). Therefore, affected individuals develop episodic hypokalemia and reduced muscle excitability in the context of low serum potassium. The episodes of weakness usually resolve within a couple of hours after onset but can last for several days. The respiratory muscles, bulbar muscles, and extraocular muscles are typically spared during these episodes, and in between episodes, patients typically have normal serum potassium levels.
questions.hint: This ECG shows T-wave flattening in the limb leads, prominent U waves in the precordial leads (with fusion of the T and U waves), ST-segment depression in I, II, and V2 to V6, and a prolonged PR interval.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes presents with generalized fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and decreased libido. He also reports abdominal pain, constipation, and difficulty swallowing.
On physical examination, he has frontal balding, bradycardia, mild gynecomastia, bilateral facial weakness, and a nasal voice. There is moderate wasting and weakness of the hand muscles bilaterally, but no fasciculations are noted. Tapping of the muscles with a reflex hammer results in sustained contraction. There is symmetric quadriceps weakness bilaterally.
Electrocardiography reveals a prolonged PR interval.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative condition that is associated with muscle weakness and fasciculations. It does not lead to myotonia and is not associated with primary hypogonadism.

B) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular-junction disorder that can result in proximal muscle weakness and extraocular-movement abnormalities. It is not associated with cardiac arrhythmias or muscle wasting.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis can be associated with diabetes mellitus and hypogonadism but does not result in muscle wasting or myotonia.

D) CORRECT:

Myotonic dystrophy, the most common form of muscular dystrophy in adults, affects approximately 1 in 8000 persons worldwide. It is a chronic, slowly progressive disease that can involve several organ systems. Patients may present with muscle weakness or with a combination of non-neurologic symptoms before developing muscle disease. Myotonia can be present several years before muscle weakness manifests. Diabetes mellitus, primary hypogonadism (low levels of serum testosterone, elevated levels of serum follicle-stimulating hormone, oligospermia, and infertility), and testicular atrophy are common problems in patients with myotonic dystrophy type 1. Bradycardia, first-degree heart block, and other electrophysiological abnormalities such as atrial and ventricular arrhythmias may require insertion of a permanent pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator to prevent sudden death in these patients.

Key learning point: Facial weakness, myotonia, cardiac arrhythmia, type 2 diabetes, and hypogonadism together suggest the diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Wilson disease can cause neuropsychiatric symptoms and liver disease but usually does not affect skeletal muscle or cause electrophysiological abnormalities.

questions.text: You are seeing a 9-year-old boy for a well-child examination. His mother reports that his teachers have noticed he is easily distracted, falls behind his classmates in most subjects, and frequently falls asleep during class. She also mentions that he has complained of leg pain on several occasions. He is at the 45th percentile for height and 35th percentile for weight. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has ptosis and a high-arched palate. Muscle strength is decreased in the face and hands, but strength in the quadriceps and hamstrings is normal. Sensation is intact. Percussion of the thenar eminence causes the thumb to abduct and then relax slowly. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Becker muscular dystrophy manifests with muscle weakness in boys between the ages of 5–10. However, this weakness typically involves the proximal muscles of the lower limb (thigh and hip muscles). Extraocular muscles and distal muscles of the upper limb are almost always spared.

B) CORRECT:

Myotonia (as indicated by abduction of the thumb followed by slow relaxation upon percussion), myalgia, and muscle weakness in the distal muscles (hand and/or foot), face, as well as extraocular muscles, are highly suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy. Reduced fetal temporalis and pterygoid muscle growth results in a high-arched palate. About 50% of patients with myotonic dystrophy have some degree of cognitive impairment. Other clinical features that are commonly associated with myotonic dystrophy include frontal balding, which typically develops during adolescence, testicular atrophy or features of ovarian insufficiency, and bilateral cataracts. The diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy can be established by electromyography and genetic testing.

Type 1 myotonic dystrophy can develop at birth, during childhood, or during adulthood.

Key learning point: Myotonic dystrophy is characterized by distal muscle weakness, myotonia (delayed muscle relaxation), facial involvement, high-arched palate, and often cognitive impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain mild forms of spinal muscular atrophy (SMA; e.g., Kugelberg-Welander disease) may manifest during late childhood with limb weakness and muscle pain (due to cramps). However, unlike in this patient, proximal muscles of the lower limb are usually more severely affected. Also, the upper cranial nerve nuclei are typically spared in patients with SMA and ptosis would therefore not be present. Although certain motor milestones may be delayed, cognitive development is typically normal in children with spinal muscular atrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis may present with myotonia. However, the myotonia in patients with hyperkalemic periodic paralysis characteristically increases with fasting, after exercise, or in cold weather. Moreover, patients typically present with dramatic episodes of weakness that predominantly affect proximal muscles rather than the insidiously developing distal muscle weakness seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

McArdle disease may result in muscle weakness, myalgia, and exercise intolerance. However, McArdle disease usually manifests during late adolescence or early adulthood and results in generalized muscle weakness or weakness that affects proximal muscles more than distal ones. One characteristic feature of McArdle disease is the second wind phenomenon, i.e., the relief of muscle pain and weakness after a brief episode of rest, which is absent in this patient.
questions.hint: This autosomal dominant condition is caused by an expansion of a CTG trinucleotide repeat in the DMPK gene.
